newsitem.title: USA: U.S. sets anti-cancer safety standard for workers.
newsitem.headline: U.S. sets anti-cancer safety standard for workers.

text.p: U.S. authorities set new limits Thursday on worker exposure to methylene chloride to help slash the risk of cancer from the solvent.
"With the new standard we expect to save 34 lives a year," U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration administrator Joseph Dear said.
About 237,500 workers are exposed to the solvent, commonly used to strip paint, clean metal parts, and produce foam cushions.

OSHA said the new standard, to be phased in over three years, should cut worker exposure to methylene chloride by 95 percent and lower the risk of cancer by 97 percent, with better ventilation, new equipment or substitute chemicals.

The rule has been in preparation for about 10 years, prompted by autoworkers who wanted the chemical controlled after studies showed that methylene chloride caused cancer in rats and mice. Auto manufacturers have already replaced the chemical in their paint stripping operations.
It would limit exposure over eight-hour periods to 25 parts of methylene chloride per million parts of air. Short-term exposure would be limited to 125 parts per million in 15-minute periods.

Workers breathing methylene chloride at concentrations of more than 25 parts per million over a working lifetime "face an intolerably high cancer risk," according to OSHA's director of health standards, Adam Finkel.
OSHA estimated the costs of meeting the new standard would total about $100 million each year for all sites, or less than three percent of profits for most industries.
Methylene chloride has been banned in cosmetics, mainly hairspray, and is no longer used for decaffeinating coffee.
